abstract: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”
lead_paragraph: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”

headline.main: One Investor’s Dow Jones Dream: $100 Per Share
